awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Naturally Derived Safe Adjuvant-Active Pesticide Formulations to Protect Crops from Fungal Diseases
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is the development of effective/safe pesticide systems to protect crops from fungal diseases. The demand for crop protection chemicals is expected to reach $77+ B by 2027. Despite interventions, fungal diseases cause the loss of 10–23% and 10–20% of crop pre- and post-harvest, respectively. This research will identify safe, naturally produced molecules that provide enhanced fungicidal activity. The system will be developed to address Botrytis cinerea, which causes devastating diseases on 500+ plant species, particularly fresh fruits and vegetables, and results in economic losses ranging from $10 billion to $100 billion worldwide; the project will then address Phakopsora pachyrhizi, the cause of Asian soybean rust (SBR). 

The proposed project addresses the fundamental difficulty that, while agricultural adjuvants can improve the efficiency of agrochemicals against plant pathogens increasing crop yields and productivities, achieving this goal is dependent on fungicide-adjuvant relative doses, crop type, and physical characteristics of spray formulations. The latter is critical to facilitate the sticking of active-adjuvant formulations onto leaves. This project develops capabilities in sophorolipid (SL) modification chemistries to generate a library of compounds. Then, a high-throughput screening assay will allow rapid assessment of adjuvant-fungicide beneficial synergies. In parallel, to assess the potential for topical and systemic toxicities, selected adjuvant-fungicide combinations will be evaluated on fibroblast and kidney cell lines. SL analogs will also be tested for growth inhibition of a representative panel of non-pathogenic rhizobacteria. Also, in planta phytotoxicity will be studied using the detached leaf assay method. Fundamental interfacial and physical characterizations of the spraying formulation will determine the extent that active-adjuvant formulations stick onto leaves. Natural component and MSL structural characteristics that lead to compatibility with fungicides for crop protection will provide a foundation to inform expanded studies on a wider range of plant pathogens and crop types.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pesticides are critical to agricultural systems as they kill pests, such as fungal pathogens, that infect food bearing crops.  Since the mid-20th Century, fungal diseases effects on crops have increased in both scale and severity. Fungal diseases represent a serious threat to global food security. Despite disease interventions, fungal diseases cause the loss of an estimated 10–23% of our crop’s pre-harvest, and an additional 10–20% post-harvest.  Fungi target commodity crops, such as barley, coffee, and bananas as well as essential calorie crops that include soybean, maize, wheat, and rice.  The economic stability of many countries is reliant upon export revenues generated by international trading of these crops. Safe pesticide formulations are needed since their toxicity can result in serious harm to non-target organisms in pesticide treated ecosystems. At risk are numerous beneficial microorganisms such as cyanobacteria and algae as well as aquatic organisms such as invertebrates, fish, amphibians, and terrestrial insects. While exposure to pesticides is most extreme at crop growing fields, pesticides are also pervasive in public or private parks, gardens, along roads and other locations.  Botrytis cinerea was selected as the primary fungal pathogen for this program as it causes devastating diseases on more than 500 plant species, especially on fresh fruits and vegetables, resulting in economic losses ranging from $10 billion to $100 billion worldwide. This fungal pathogen invades nearly all parts of plants including stems, leaves, flowers, fruits, and seeds at both pre-harvest and post-harvest stages.  Pesticide formulations consist of active fungicides and adjuvants. These components result in complex interactions that are not well understood.  A fundamental difficulty is that, while agricultural adjuvants can improve the efficiency of the fungicide ingredient increasing crop yields and productivities, achieving this goal is highly dependent on fungicide-adjuvant relative doses, the prevailing climate, crop type, physical characteristics of spray formulations that enable active-adjuvant formulations to stick onto leaves, chemical stability while in formulations and safety to exposed ecosystems.

 

This program exploited the strong potential of yeast produced natural sophorolipids (SLs) as an ecologically safe and economically viable platform for adjuvant molecules.  Their physical and biological properties were varied by their modification using simple, safe, and scalable ‘green’ synthetic methods. This provided a broad landscape of fungicide-SL adjuvant combinations to explore.  The library of modified SL-fungicides was formulated varying the relative concentrations of modified SL structure-fungicide ingredients. This library was then assessed by Croda’s high-throughput adjuvant development platform. Synergistic effects of modified SL adjuvant-fungicide formulations that led to enhanced plant fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea killing at lower fungicide concentrations in combination with reduced toxicity against normal cell lines were identified.  This program resulted in the identification of modified SL/fungicide combinations that have superior pesticide performance against pathogen-crop systems relative to existing Croda products.  However, further work including field studies will be needed to verify laboratory results.  Furthermore, participation in the National I-Corp program led to an understanding of target customer segments, value propositions and cost targets of the new pesticides. Finally, the PFI program has provided a basis for continued exploration of microbial surfactant adjuvant/fungicide actives to fill gaps on numerous other pathogen-crop challenges.
